data.title: Looney Tunes character cameos in non LT/LT related media
data.meta_description: This is a thread where we post or discuss Looney Tunes characters making cameos in non Looney Tunes or LT-related stuff (ie, Tiny Toons, Taz-Mania). In what...
data.text:
Zorak Masaki

Well-Known Member

Joined

May 6, 2002

Messages

9,015

Mar 9, 2024

#1

This is a thread where we post or discuss Looney Tunes characters making cameos in non Looney Tunes or LT-related stuff (ie, Tiny Toons, Taz-Mania). In what may be the first example, Bugs Bunny made a cameo in the George Pal Puppettoon Jasper Goes Hunting. For a more unusual example Wile E Coyote actually made an appearance on Night Court (it was one of those "night of 1000 cases" episodes, where they could get away with insanity like that)

Bugs Bunny appeared in a dream sequence in two movies: “Two Guys from Texas”, (1948), and “My Dream is Yours” (1949).

#7

I think there are a few Cartoon Network promos and bumpers where the Looney Tunes interacted with other characters. Not sure if those count, same goes for parodies (i.e., Family Guy).

Do we count instances where characters are shown watching Looney Tunes clips on TV? Off the top of my head, clips from "The Great Piggy Bank Robbery" were used in both Son of Batman and Teen Titans: The Judas Contract.

Foghorn Leghorn once appeared in a series…”I say”, a series of commercials for Kentucky Fried Chicken (“chicken”, “that is”).

#10

Bugs and Daffy were among those appearing in the 1990 anti-drug special Cartoon All-Stars to the Rescue... which also had an allusion to Wile E. Coyote as the source of a time machine Bugs had acquired.

Another all-star special (albeit not all cartoons) from that year was The Earth Day Special, which included Bugs, Porky and Tweety. Both specials had Jeff Bergman voicing all the LT characters, having been made shortly after the death of Mel Blanc.

Bugs Bunny appeared in a dream sequence in two movies: “Two Guys from Texas”, (1948), and “My Dream is Yours” (1949).

Sent from my iPhone using Tapatalk

Which were both made by Warner Bros.!

I think there are a few Cartoon Network promos and bumpers where the Looney Tunes interacted with other characters. Not sure if those count, same goes for parodies (i.e., Family Guy).

Do we count instances where characters are shown watching Looney Tunes clips on TV? Off the top of my head, clips from "The Great Piggy Bank Robbery" were used in both Son of Batman and Teen Titans: The Judas Contract.

A clip from "Hare Ribbin'" was used in Batman Beyond: Return of the Joker.

#13

Some examples I can think of:

- Gremlins 2: The New Batch opens with an animated segment (written and directed by Chuck Jones) with Bugs and Daffy fighting over who gets to sit on top of the WB shield

- The short-lived ABC variety show Pat Paulsen's Half a Comedy Hour featured Daffy Duck and Foghorn Leghorn as "guest stars"

- Bugs Bunny has a couple brief appearances in the 1974 independent short film A Political Cartoon

- The final episode of Two and a Half Men features cameo appearances by a CG-animated Porky Pig (wearing a bra and panties) and Pepe Le Pew

- The 2012 MetLife commercial "Everyone" features cameo appearances by Pepe Le Pew, Speedy Gonzales, Yosemite Sam, Marvin the Martian, Gossamer, and Witch Hazel

#14

There was also an ad for a baseball cap among other products around the time Tim Burton's Batman movie came out.

Too bad the video can't be viewed directly in this thread.

That's actually a special version of a commercial that appears on other Warner Bros. home video releases (the original version just has the WB shield logo). The Batman version appears on the original home video release of the movie from 1989.

There is also a series of PSAs called "An Ounce of Prevention", which talk about being safe around the house. For instance, Bugs reminds everyone to "keep those pot handles turned in", while Daffy talks to a boy and a girl about fire safety.

Sent from my SM-T220 using Tapatalk

Cartoonland

Mar 10, 2024

#15

In Lethal Weapon (1987) Det. Martin Riggs (Mel Gibson) is watching the TV special Bugs Bunny's Looney Christmas Tales in his home.

In Innerspace (also 1987), store clerk Jack Putter (Martin Short) enters the apartment of test pilot Lt. Tuck Pendelton (Dennis Quaid); among the items in Pendleton's home is a Bugs Bunny plushie.

Peter Bogdanovich's screwball comedy What's Up, Doc? (1972) ends with a clip of the Looney Tunes short of the same name playing on a TV.

All of these movies were produced by Warner Bros.

Also, in The Cure's music video for their song "Lovecats", one scene features a bunch of people in cat costumes; one of them is wearing a Sylvester costume.

#17

I guess the infamous Daffy Duck and Porky Pig Meet the Groovie Goolies from 1972 fits in with a lot of what's being mentioned here. Several other LT/MM characters also appear in it, although like the post-1964 shorts Bugs was off limits.

We do have a previous thread about clips of cartoons appearing in movies, but while we're on it I'll mention the Road Runner clips (from Beep Beep on a TV and Woah, Be-Gone! at a Drive-In) in Steven Spielberg's first theatrical film (Duel was made for TV) The Sugarland Express; he notes how important securing these clips was for him in his Foreword to Chuck Jones' first book Chuck Amuck.

We do have a previous thread about clips of cartoons appearing in movies, but while we're on it I'll mention the Road Runner clips (from Beep Beep on a TV and Woah, Be-Gone! at a Drive-In) in Steven Spielberg's first theatrical film (Duel was made for TV) The Sugarland Express; he notes how important securing these clips was for him in his Foreword to Chuck Jones' first book Chuck Amuck.

Speaking of which, I didn't mention it in that thread because it's technically not a movie, but the pilot episode of Sue Thomas: F.B.Eye features clips from Tweety's first cartoon, "A Tale of Two Kitties" (I only know this because I happened to walk in on my mom watching it once).

I was quite surprised to see Devil's Feud Cake (1963) playing in an episode of Supernatural. Strangely, the cartoon was being shown on an airplane. I wanna know what flights show classic cartoons- I want on THAT flight!

A little off-topic, but I do remember being on a flight once where a Pink Panther cartoon was one of the on-demand viewing options.

In Justice League: The New Frontier there's a brief scene where Martian Manhunter turns into Bugs Bunny after watching TV (we don't see any footage but Bugs' voice is heard in the background, provided by Joe Alaskey).
